title: Photo Deconstruction: Colorful Editorial Hair Shoot with Gels
summary: Photographer Lindsay Adler breaks down a creative editorial hair photoshoot, demonstrating a five-light setup using colored gels, camera settings, and post-processing techniques to achieve a vibrant, high-contrast look.

steps.action: Set up the main light to illuminate the center of the face with a narrow beam of white light.
Position two back rim lights with strip softboxes and gels (Magenta on left, Green on right).
Add two front fill lights using zoom reflectors with gels contrasting the rim lights (Green on left, Magenta on right).
Select a dark gray background to absorb excess light and provide contrast.
Configure camera settings for sharpness and depth of field.
Adjust Raw settings by desaturating the green channel slightly and cooling the white balance to shift colors towards teal/purple.
Use the Liquify tool to add volume to the hair, elongate the neck, and refine the jawline.
Build the lighting setup step-by-step while shooting tethered, starting with the main light and adding gels one by one.

key_takeaways: Mixing complementary colored lights (like Magenta and Green) can create white light where they overlap.
Hard light modifiers (grids, zoom reflectors) are effective for emphasizing hair texture.
Using contrasting colors for rim and fill lights (e.g., Pink rim vs Green fill) creates visual separation and pop.
Establish the lighting and pose with a static subject before introducing movement like wind.
Liquify is a crucial tool in hair photography to create shape, flow, and volume that wasn't captured in camera.
